thread.title: Woodside CEO Peter Coleman to chair Africa investment advisory group
thread.title_full: Woodside CEO Peter Coleman to chair Africa investment advisory group

title: Woodside CEO Peter Coleman to chair Africa investment advisory group
text:
WOODSIDE Petroleum boss Peter Coleman will head a new advisory group on Africa as the federal government trumpets investment over aid.
Foreign Minister Julie Bishop says the expansion of trade and investment links between Australia and Africa will continue to be underpinned by mining investment.
“Our belief is that economic development drives poverty alleviation,” Ms Bishop told the Africa Downunder mining conference. Foreign Affairs minister Julie Bishop Source: News Corp Australia
Mr Coleman’s appointment to a new government advisory group comes after the federal government cut the foreign aid budget for Africa by 70 per cent in May.
Ms Bishop hopes the group will eventually become commercially viable.
“This group of eminent representatives from business, civil society and the public sector will inform the Australian government’s thinking and policies on Africa,” Ms Bishop said.
Australian trade in Africa had increased from $7 billion to $10 billion between 2009 and 2014, and mining would continue to make a substantial contribution to economic development in Africa, Ms Bishop said.
Around 200 Australian listed companies operate more than 700 resources projects in Africa.
Woodside is expanding its oil and gas exploration presence in Africa, several years after pulling out of Mauritania.
Ms Bishop added that Australia was providing more than $500 million in support for development and security in Africa, but conceded the nation’s foreign aid program now focused on the Asia Pacific region.
Originally published as Woodside boss to chair Africa group
